draw:text-box.text:p: Binary ArtByte-ing the PE that fails you
I will speak about the Portable Executable file format.

text:p.text:span: I'm the author of a website called Corkami.
this talk is about the Portable Executable file format, aka PE files.
It's based on the Unix Common Object File Format.
even if you never heard about the PE file format, if you ran any of these under Windows, you used a PE file.
all executables under Windows use that format.
but also drivers, dlls, screensavers, control panels, activeX component, .Net, etc...
on a standard Windows system, there are really a lot of PE files.
Here are all the DLLs used by a normal Windows 7 system.
but PE files are not just used for executables, they are even used for code-less resources containers.

draw:text-box.text:p: so, the PE file format is really the universal Windows binary format

text:p.text:span: if you're completely new to the PE file format, I did an introduction poster. feel free to download it, share it, print it.

draw:text-box.text:p: what's the problem about PE file format?
the official Microsoft is far from describing everything.
At best, it can be used to understand what happens in a standard PE made by a standard compiler.
It's far from documenting every possibility.
This is not enough for the modern infosec world.
with weird PE files, you could crash an OS or a security tool, which is not good for end users.

text:p.text:span: the lack of documentation can also be a problem for developers:

a specific compiler generated a header value that Windows 7's official component was rejecting, which means any of the files generated by that legitimate compiler would be rejected by Applocker as being non-executable, even if it would work perfectly otherwise.
If you prevent developers to use your OS, you're in danger.

draw:text-box.text:p: or you can fool a scanner into believing this is NOT a PE, thus being reported as clean by evading a scan of the executable code.
Here, a PE reported as an old DOS executable (likely benign), or a PDF document.
the other problem is that a specially crafted PE could thwart (automated) analysis.
Here, a trivial example of a one-byte patch to prevent kindergarten-level unpacking.
It's a kind of lame example, but I still see a lot of malware writeups relying on UPX itself to unpack.
and of course, you might even crash the most advanced reverse engineering tools, which would prevent (or at least delay) even manual analysis by experts.
looking at what's existing in the wild could be a waste of time, and would limit me in my approach. I wouldn't know in advance what could exist.
so I looked at documentations, unespecially unofficial ones, and start playing lego.
you know, you learn the rules, then you just put bricks together, and you see if it holds or falls.
of course, I'm talking about this kind of low-level legos.
so you put things together... not with actual bricks maybe, but with blocks of assembler.
and eventually, you actually get something that works!
it's the same thing on both side: a working executable defined with only very few elements.

text:p.text:span: so I repeated that process, exploring the format, writing by hands 170 various executables.
and I wrote a summary of my findings on pe.corkami.com
so let's have a look at 'Le PE' :)

draw:text-box.text:p: an executable file starts with the PE, and may have appended data.

text:p.text:span: appended data is extra data that will be ignored by the PE loader, and not loaded in memory. It's not defined by the PE header.
a PE is made of a header, and Sections. Sections basically contain everything that is not the header:
the header itself is made of 2 generations of headers.
the old dos header, that was introduced in IBM PC DOS in 1981.
then, for backward compatibility, modern headers could follow it (not just the PE, the NE format was introduced in 1985 for Windows 1.0).
you could just create your own header, knowing that the old dos header with old code would keep backward compatibility.
from now on, I'll just focus on the PE header, introduced for Windows 3.11 in 1993
and the PE files for modern Windows, which means x86 or x64 code.

draw:page.draw:name: between the hammer and the anvil

text:p.text:span: Also, for completeness, some 'non header' data is typically present between the DOS and the PE headers.

draw:text-box.text:p: first, some minimal 16b code from the DOS era, still present even on Windows 8 64b.
and the 'undocumented' Rich header (it has the word 'Rich' in second to last position), that is passive information from the compiler.
Both DOS stub and Rich header don't interfere in PE loading, and are completely ignored.

text:list-item.text:p: tells where the PE header is.

draw:text-box.text:p: the DOS header, circa 1981, is almost irrelevant.
it needs to start with the letters MZ, and its last element, e_lfanew, is a dword that points to the modern headers, (PE or anything)
the PE headers is made of 2 parts, which it took from the COFF format.
the NT headers (which shows it's windows-specific), and the section table.
the NT headers starts with a PE\0\0 signature, then the File header, then an Optional header, which is present only on executables, not objects.
the FileHeader contents defines the presence or not of the Optional header, and the section table.

text:list-item.text:p: code, data, uninitialized data, imports, resources...
which part of the file goes where
defining in parallel a name, location, and ordinal
a function can have several names
API names and future API addresses
ImportsAddressTable just highlight the adress parts
different ImageBase given by the loader
requires only 3 APIs calls to be used
Callbacks executed on thread start and stop
bigger than file (→ virtual table, xp)
Extra padding is required since Vista
Data directory only read in memory
data directories overlaps starts of section
Descriptor is skipped if no thunk
terminator can be virtual or outside file
usually with a lot of compilers library
type MIPS and IA64 are present on all archs
Packers put some data or jumps there
NumberOfRvaAndSizes should be 14 at least, right?
the Windows executable format is complex
ignored if a different path is required to reach resource

draw:text-box.text:p: → a PE with low alignments and no imports can work in all 3 subsystems
